column2: smallimage          = <!--If this is specified, ""image"" should not be.-->

column10: archive-date=28 June 2018 }}</ref> is a British judge. He was a [[Lord Justice of Appeal]] in [[Courts of England and Wales
column11: England and Wales]] from 2011 to 2018, and became [[President of the Family Division]] in July 2018 upon Sir [[James Munby]]’s retirement from that office.

column5: sep=,}} (born 19 June 1950) is a retired British judge and [[barrister]]. From 2008 to 2019, she was a Justice of the [[High Court of England and Wales]].

column2: West Midlands]], before moving to [[Crosby, Merseyside]].<ref name="":0"">{{Cite web
column3: title=The family justice man: Sir Andrew McFarlane P
column7: language=en}}</ref> He was educated at [[Shrewsbury School]] and studied law at [[Collingwood College, Durham]], and graduated in 1975.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title = Wood Words 2010/11}}</ref> He was an early member of Durham University Sensible Thespians (later renamed [[List of social activities at Durham University#Durham Revue
column10: The Durham Revue]]), a sketch comedy group founded in 1973.<ref>{{cite web

column1: +Judith Parker was born on 19 June 1950.<ref name=Birth>{{cite web
+Mrs Justice Parker 63 }}</ref> She studied [[Jurisprudence]] at [[Somerville College, Oxford]],<ref name=""Debrett's"">{{cite web
column9: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in 1972.<ref name=""Who's Who 2016"">{{cite web
column10: title=PARKER, Hon. Dame Judith Mary Frances

column1: +Parker is an Honorary Fellow of Somerville College.<ref>{{cite web

-McFarlane was [[called to the bar]] at [[Gray's Inn]] in 1977 and has been a [[Bencher]] since 2003. He began his [[pupillage]] in London at chancery chambers before moving to 2 Fountain Court in [[Birmingham]] (now St Philips Chambers). While there, he and David Hershman wrote ''Hershman and McFarlane: Children Law and Practice''. He then moved to 1 King’s Bench Walk in [[Temple, London]] in 1994.<ref name="":0"" /> In 1998, he became a [[Queen's Counsel]].

+In 1973, Parker was [[called to the Bar]] by [[Middle Temple]].<ref name=""Who's Who 2016"" /> She then specialised in [[family law]].<ref name=""Debrett's"" /> On 9 April 1991, she was appointed [[Queen's Counsel]] (QC).<ref name=""LG 12 April 1991"">{{London Gazette

-He was appointed an Assistant Recorder in 1995, a Recorder in 1999 and a deputy High Court Judge in 2000. He was appointed as a judge of the [[High Court of Justice]] on 18 April 2005<ref>{{London Gazette
column4: date=21 April 2005}}</ref> and assigned to the [[High Court of Justice#Family Division
column5: Family Division]], receiving the customary [[Knight Bachelor
column6: knighthood]]. McFarlane was the Family Division Liaison Judge for the Midland [[Circuit court#England and Wales
column7: Circuit]] from 2006 until his appointment as a [[Lord Justice of Appeal]]<ref>{{cite press release
column9: title=Appointment of Lords Justices of Appeal
column18: date=2 August 2011}}</ref> whereupon he received the customary appointment to the [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom
column19: Privy Council]]. On  28 July 2018, he was appointed [[President of the Family Division]].<ref>{{Cite web
column20: title=Biography of The Rt Hon Sir Andrew McFarlane, President of the Family Division and Chair of the Family Justice Council

column1: +Between 1998 and 2000, Parker served as an [[Recorder (judge)#Recorders as part-time appointments
column2: assistant recorder]] (i.e. a part-time judge).<ref name=""Debrett's"" /> On 7 March 2000, she was appointed a [[Master of the Bench]] of Middle Temple.<ref name=""bio - Middle Temple"">{{cite web
column6: publisher=The Honourable Society of the Middle Temple
column7: accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> On 18 July 2000, she was appointed a [[Recorder (judge)
column8: Recorder]], and served as a part-time judge on the [[South Eastern Circuit]].<ref name=""LG 24 July 2000"">{{London Gazette

column1: -He is the President of Tribunals and Chair of the Clergy Discipline Commission of the [[Church of England]] under the Clergy Discipline Measure 2003.<ref>{{cite web
+On 13 June 2008, Parker was appointed a [[High Court judge (England and Wales)
column2: Judge]] assigned to the [[Family Division]] of the [[High Court of Justice]].<ref>{{cite web
column7: accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> She was appointed [[Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (DBE) shortly after being appointed.<ref name=""Who's Who 2016"" /> In 2018, during an unknown hearing, she dozed off momentarily, for which she was given official advice.<ref>{{cite web
column12: accessdate=9 Feb 2019}}</ref> She retired shortly after.
